The fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024 script

Introduction

A typical testbuddy-g5k project will have an entrypoint, it will have some tarball results and other auxiliary scripts for processing the results further.

In the fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024 directory lies an example of a project that testbuddy-g5k can work with. The files entrypoint.bash and entrypoint.py are essentially the entrypoint, meaning the script that will run in one of the hosts when the cluster resources are available. There’s a Bash and a Python script because the Bash script sets up the python3-requests dependency before executing the Python script. The load_db.py script is a post-processing script that will load the tarballed data into an SQLite3 database, whose schema is described below in The SQL schema section. The plot.py file will load data from the database and create Plotly plots which will be stored in HTML files in the given output directory.

  • The config/fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024.toml configuration file contains the configuration to launch these experiments.

  • The fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/entrypoint.bash script is the entrypoint that installs the Python3 requests Debian package. This is important because the real entrypoint, fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/entrypoint.py uses requests to interact with the Grid’5000 REST API.

  • The fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/load_db.py script will import the tarballed results into an SQLite3 database. The database is created if it does not exist.

  • The fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/plot.py script will plot the results of a database, creating HTML files inside the specified directory.

Example session

We illustrate the use of testbuddy-g5k and the fenicsx-tetss-gsoc2024 scripts in the following section. This is a typical use of them to perform experiments and create HTML plots.

Launching experiments

We can launch experiments with:

testbuddy-g5k -c config/fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024.toml launch

Or if we are interested in running on every number of cores of a single host, we can instead do:

testbuddy-g5k -c config/fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024.toml launch --grd-options host=1 --override-options --script-args --single-host

Note

With --script-args --single-host we are telling testbuddy-g5k to pass the option --single-host to the entrypoint, which activates the single-host mode for fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024: instead of running on max cores available, run from 1 to max cores available. Reasonably, we tell testbuddy-g5k to only allocate one host with --grd-options host=1 and for this option to override any host configuration with --override-options, since the config/fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024.toml configuration file specifies other numbers of hosts.

Downloading the tarballs

We can sync the results with:

testbuddy-g5k -c config/fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024.toml sync

The configured directory under the [sync] section is ./www/results and that is where the tarballs will be stored, but it can be changed. Note that tarballs are named according to ISO 8601 universal time date, i.e. as in the output of date -uIs of date(1) and to be extracted you must use the --force-local option to tar(1).

Note

You typically don’t have to inspect the tarballs yourself. The fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/load_db.py will load them into an SQLite3 database.

Loading the results in a database

If we’d like to create a brand new database, we can do:

./fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/load_db.py -c config/fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024.toml -d results.db

This will load all the results of www/results into a database called results.db. This script takes care to not create duplicate rows, so you can use it as many times as you’d like; it will do nothing if there are no new results.

Plotting the results into graphs

With the command

./fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024/plot.py -d results.db www/plots

we are instructing the script to load the results.db database and create four HTML files named strong_poisson.html, weak_poisson.html, strong_elasticity.html, and weak_elasticity.html into the directory www/plots.

The SQL schema

The database contains a single table called results which contains all the results of the experiments. We explain all the columns of the results table. Keep in mind that an experiment can be a batch of results; each result is a row entry. To clarify further, an experiment will run both Poisson and Elasticity problems, in both weak and strong scaling; each combination is a single result resulting in a row entry. An experiment is essentially an invocation of the fenicsx-tests-gsoc2024 entrypoint in a particular group of hosts in a cluster.

Warning

Some of the column names contain dots . and hyphens -. SQLite3 will require you to double-quote these identifiers to operate on them, see SQLite Keywords.

id:

An incrementing integer that is unique to the row entry.

date:

The date when the experiment group was conducted in ISO-8601 format.

date_id:

A random string; together with date, they are unique to an experiment (but not to a result; see above, many results can be performed in a single experiment.)

experiment.command:

The command that gave the results; typically starts with mpiexec ....

experiment.cores:

The number of cores used in the experiment. This is smaller than total cores available when --cores-mode=single-host.

experiment.dof:

The degrees of freedom used.

experiment.exit_status:

The exit status of experiment.command.

experiment.libblas_choice:

The particular BLAS implementation used.

experiment.problem_type:

The problem type, either poisson or elasticity.

experiment.scaling_type:

The scaling type, either weak or strong.

experiment.stderr:

The stderr of the experiment.command.

experiment.stdout:

The stdout of the experiment.command.

grid5000.arch:

The architecture as reported by uname; usually x86_64.

grid5000.cluster:

The name of the Grid’5000 cluster.

grid5000.grd_jobid:

The ID of the Grid’5000 job. Information about jobs is permanently stored in Grid’5000 servers; useful for debugging.

grid5000.host.isa:

The architecture as reported by Grid’500; usually x86-64.

grid5000.host.model:

The model of the CPU as reported by Grid’5000.

grid5000.host.model_other:

The model of the CPU as reported by Grid’5000 (more details.)

grid5000.host.sockets:

The number of sockets of the CPU.

grid5000.host.total_cores:

The total number of cores available to the host; the number of CPU cores multiplied by number of sockets.

grid5000.hosts:

The number of hosts reserved in the cluster.

grid5000.login:

The login username to Grid’5000.

grid5000.site:

The Grid’5000 site in which the clusters belong to; grenoble, rennes, and so on.

grid5000.total_cores:

The total number of cores reserved; i.e. the number of hosts times the cores in each.

software.dolfinx_parameters.hypre:

A boolean true or false. Whether hypre is enabled or not. Hypre is disabled when complex math is enabled.

software.packages.fenicsx-performance-tests:

The version of the Debian package fenicsx-performance-tests.

software.packages.BLAS_PKG:

The version of the Debian package $BLAS_PKG; which BLAS packages are installed depends on --blas (see also --blas-all.)

software.uname:

The uname --kernel-name --kernel-release --kernel-version string.

Also the following timings are available, but we do not individually describe them; they are all grabbed from the table printed in the stdout output of the DOLFINx tested program. Some comments on their particular meaning can be found on this FEniCS discourse post. We merely point out that wall_tot is the total wall time a particular step took, while reps is the number of repetitions of that step.

timings.build_box_mesh.wall_avg:

timings.build_box_mesh.wall_tot:

Finally there is a schema version, currently set at 1.0.

version:

1.0, the schema version. If the schema changes, this version will change.
